Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Providing Automatic System Anomaly Management Software as a Service for Dynamic Complex Computing Infrastructures
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to greatly improve the robustness and diagnosability of many computing infrastructures including both public and private computing clouds. The proposed technology will significantly reduce the occurrence of performance degradation and service downtime in cloud computing infrastructures, which can attract more users to adopt cloud computing technology and thus benefit society as a whole, which depends increasingly on cloud technology. The project will also advance the state of the art in cloud system reliability research by putting research results into real world use.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will transform system anomaly management for dynamic complex computing infrastructures. The novelty of the company's solution lies in three unique features: 1) predictive: the solution can raise advance alerts before a serious service outage occurs; 2) self-learning: the solution automatically infers alert conditions and performs automatic root cause analysis using machine learning algorithms; 3) adaptive: the technology adapts to dynamic systems. The proposed research will produce novel and practical anomaly prediction and diagnosis solutions that will be validated in real world computing infrastructures. Specifically, the project consists of three thrusts: 1) adaptive learning in dynamic environments; 2) real-time feature extraction and pattern recognition over system metric and log data; and 3) full stack root cause analysis. During the project the company will implement its software products and carry out case studies with prospective customers on real world computing infrastructures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In March 2017, we received an NSF SBIR Phase II and Phase IIB grant to develop a real-time, unsupervised machine learning-based system anomaly management software-as-a-service product that does not exist in today's market. We first developed our adaptive learning framework to handle dynamic production systems by constructing a pool of models for monitored infrastructure and developed adaptive model selection algorithms to pick the right model for detecting anomalies in stream monitoring data. We then developed pattern recognition and labelling techniques that can extract different event patterns from raw anomaly data and allow the user to name those event patterns. Next, we developed full stack anomaly diagnosis solutions and self-healing action triggering system based on our diagnosis results. We performed a set of integrations with popular big data platforms and implement a user friendly graphical interface for the user to view real time insights we extracted from various machine data. 


Our research during Phase II and Phase IIB projects aim at answering a set of key commercialization feasibility questions: 1) can our adaptive learning techniques handle dynamic production computing environments? 2) can our anomaly pattern extraction techniques discover all unique patterns across logs, metrics, and events? 3) can our distributed causal analysis algorithms pinpoint right root causes for production problems? and 4) can integrated analysis provide better predictability and more accurate root causes than siloed tools? We carried out data-driven research study to answer those questions. 


We evaluated our learning and prediction algorithms using both our own production deployment within Amazon AWS cloud and our customers' production environments. Our evaluations with several large enterprise customers show that we can predict over 90% most severe incidents in real world with 2-12 hours lead time. We also identified true root causes in our automatically ranked top likely root causes. Compared to siloed tools such as Dynatrace, Science Logic, and Service Now, only our product can provide user desired incident prediction and root cause capabilities. Those key differentiating features are the major reasons for large enterprise customers to adopt InsightFinder. We also conducted extensive scalability and robustness tests. Our results show that our anomaly detection algorithms can scale to hundreds of thousands of different metrics while our competitors can only support orders of magnitude less metrics and also require costly GPU. Our product has been adopted by several Fortune 500 companies.  


Last Modified: 01/08/2021
Modified by: Jeremy Neuberger

Our research during Phase II and Phase IIB projects aim at answering a set of key commercialization feasibility questions: 1) can our adaptive learning techniques handle dynamic production computing environments? 2) can our anomaly pattern extraction techniques discover all unique patterns across logs, metrics, and events? 3) can our distributed causal analysis algorithms pinpoint right root causes for production problems? and 4) can integrated analysis provide better predictability and more accurate root causes than siloed tools? We carried out data-driven research study to answer those questions. We evaluated our learning and prediction algorithms using both our own production deployment within Amazon AWS cloud and our customers' production environments. Compared to siloed tools such as Dynatrace, Science Logic, and Service Now, only our product can provide user desired incident prediction and root cause capabilities. Those key differentiating features are the major reasons for large enterprise customers to adopt InsightFinder. We also conducted extensive scalability and robustness tests. Our results show that our anomaly detection algorithms can scale to hundreds of thousands of different metrics while our competitors can only support orders of magnitude less metrics and also require costly GPU.
